title: Dow rises, Nasdaq falls in Friday afternoon trading as U.S. stock indexes head for weekly losses; S&P 500 rises modestly Friday afternoon
text:
* The Dow Jones Industrial Average DJIA rose almost 170 points, or 0.5%, to 33,716.

* The S&P 500 SPX was up 14 points, or 0.4%, at almost 3,961.

* The Nasdaq Composite COMP slid about 11 points, or 0.1%, to about 11,134.

For the week, the Dow is on pace to slip 0.1%, while the S&P 500 is heading for a 0.8% decline and the Nasdaq Composite is poised to drop 1.7%, according to FactSet data, at last check.

What's driving markets

Sentiment in the U.S. stock market has weakened, with all three major benchmarks heading for weekly losses.

The rally that had been sparked by the consumer-price-index report on Nov. 10 has lost steam as the S&P 500 index has risen back around its 200-day moving average, according to Anthony Saglimbene, chief market strategist at Ameriprise Financial.

"The market is having a hard time around this spot," he said in a phone interview Friday. The 200-day moving average appears to be providing some technical "resistance." FactSet data show that level at around 4,067 on Friday afternoon.

In the wake of the CPI report showing signs of the cost of living easing, the Federal Reserve Bank of Saint Louis President James Bullard said in a speech Thursday that the Fed will need to increase interest rates further to bring down inflation. He showed a chart indicating that the central bank's benchmark interest rate could rise between 5% and 7%.

"It's a very big range," said Saglimbene. "If it's 5%, the market will likely do pretty well," as that's "baked into" expectations, he said, but "if it's 7%, the market is going to do very poorly."

Today: MarketWatch Live Coverage

Andrew Hollenhorst, chief U.S. economist at Citi Research, was not surprised by Bullard's remarks as his statement is supported by the data given that "the Atlanta Fed's dashboard of underlying inflation metrics are all running above 4.7%, suggesting that policy rates will need to reach above 5% for real rates to be meaningfully positive." That is a condition both Fed Chair Jerome Powell and Vice-Chair Lael Brainard have agreed on as a requirement for restrictive monetary policy, Hollenhorst said in a note on Friday.

In U.S. economic data, the National Association of Realtors said Friday that existing-home sales fell 5.9% in October, slumping for a ninth straight month. That's down 28.4% from a year earlier.

Read : U.S. existing home sales retreat for a record ninth straight month in October

Meanwhile, the U.S. leading economic index fell 0.8% in October, an eight straight monthly decline, according to a Conference Board report Friday. That's bigger than the 0.4% fall that economists polled by The Wall Street Journal had forecast.

"The downturn in the LEI reflects consumers' worsening outlook amid high inflation and rising interest rates, as well as declining prospects for housing construction and manufacturing," said Ataman Ozyildirim, senior director of economics at the Conference Board. "The Conference Board forecasts real GDP growth will be 1.8 percent year-over-year in 2022, and a recession is likely to start around year-end and last through mid-2023."

With the housing market in a steepening slowdown and goods spending "contracting a bit," Jim Baird, chief investment officer of Plante Moran Financial Advisors, said in a phone interview Friday that he'll be watching for signs of weakening in the services sector.

"That's where the rubber will meet the road next year, if we see continued deterioration there," he said. That's when the economy would probably tip into a recession, "if we get there."

In the meantime, high inflation remains a "challenge" and risks of a recession in 2023 have risen, said Baird. "It's hard to paint an overly optimistic picture for equities in the near term."

For the week, the Dow Jones Industrial Average is on pace to slip 0.1%, while the S&P 500 is heading for a 0.8% decline and the Nasdaq Composite is poised to drop 1.7%, according to FactSet data, at last check.

On Friday, there's some $2.1 trillion of options that expire, according to a Goldman Sachs report. That can create some market volatility, said Saglimbene.

Read: More than $2 trillion in stock options expire Friday with put-call ratio near levels unseen since 2001

Companies in focus

* Gap Inc. GPS stock was 4.8% higher after the retailer swung to a surprise quarterly profit and reported sales above Wall Street's expectations, saying it expects to better match inventory with demand by spring.

* Applied Materials AMAT rose 0.5% after reporting stronger-than-expected earnings and revenue to wrap up its fiscal year Thursday, and topped expectations with its forecast for the beginning of the new year, sending shares slightly higher in after-hours trading.

* JD.com Inc. JD American depositary shares declined 2.3%, after the China-based e-commerce company reported third-quarter profit that nearly doubled to beat expectations by a wide margin.

* Coinbase COIN shares dropped after Bank of America downgraded Coinbase to neutral from buy, saying that the FTX debacle raises "contagion risk" for the crypto exchange platform, even if it is not another FTX.

â€”Steve Goldstein contributed to this report.

Dow rises, Nasdaq falls in Friday afternoon trading as U.S. stock indexes head for weekly losses
